newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish think-tank sees no room for NBP rate cut.
newsitem.headline: Polish think-tank sees no room for NBP rate cut.

text.p: The National Bank of Poland is unlikely to cut its interest rates in the near-term because of the need to curb credit growth and limit Poland's trade gap, the independent NOBE economic institute said on Friday.

It said in a quarterly macroeconomic forecast that it rather expected the central bank to further tighten its monetary policy by either raising rates or using other instruments to boost the price of money.

"As growth of domestic credit should be curbed, there is no room for interest rate cuts. To the contrary, NBP may slightly increase the basic rates in the coming months, or continue using other instruments that increase the price of money," the institute said.
NOBE also said that for the sake of helping exports growth it did not expect the central bank to let the zloty firm soon.

"Probably no one-off devaluation will be necessary, and the crawling peg will continue at its present rate of one percent a month. The crawl is unlikely to be be cut below 0.9-1 percent a month over the next four quarters," it said.
